references.name: Don’t steal my drone: Catching attackers with an unmanned aerial vehicle honeypot
references.cite: E. Vasilomanolakis, J. Daubert, D. Boopalan, and M. Mühlhäuser, “Don’t steal my drone: Catching attackers with an unmanned aerial vehicle honeypot,” IEEE/IFIP Netw. Oper. Manag. Symp. Cogn. Manag. a Cyber World, NOMS 2018, pp. 1–2, 2018, doi:10.1109/NOMS.2018.8406119 .
references.description: This paper proposes a defensive honeypot system for UAVs. The main goal is to detect and study attackers targeting UAV communication and control interfaces. The authors introduce a portable, medium-interaction UAV honeypot that emulates the radio interfaces, protocols, and basic system behaviour of real UAVs. The honeypot is intended to lure attackers away from real drones and collect detailed information about their attack techniques. It can run on low-cost hardware such as a Raspberry Pi and uses commodity wireless adapters. The threat model assumes that attackers target UAVs through wireless communication channels, often relying on signal strength rather than physical proximity or visual contact. Typical attacks include Wi-Fi de-authentication, command hijacking, unauthorised access to onboard services, and protocol-level manipulation. These attacks are assumed based on prior work and demonstrations, not newly discovered in this paper. The honeypot emulates multiple UAV-related communication technologies, including Wi-Fi-based command and control, common application protocols such as Telnet, SSH, and FTP, and UAV-specific protocols such as MAVLink. To increase realism, the system uses drone simulators (e.g., ArduPilot SITL) that expose MAVLink interfaces and simulate UAV state information such as GPS position, movement, and battery level. The honeypot also emulates UAV file systems and radio characteristics, making it difficult for attackers to distinguish it from a real drone. All attacker interactions with the honeypot are logged and stored, enabling offline analysis and replay of attack sessions. The paper presents demonstration scenarios in which known UAV attacks (e.g., Wi-Fi de-authentication followed by command hijacking or file deletion) are first performed against real UAVs and then repeated against the honeypot to show similar attacker behaviour. The paper argues that, if deployed strategically and with stronger signal characteristics than nearby UAVs, the honeypot may also divert or delay attacks against real drones. However, the system primarily functions as a detection and intelligence-gathering mechanism, not as a full prevention or recovery solution.

references.name: The Impact of DoS Attacks on the AR.Drone 2.0
references.cite: G. Vasconcelos, G. Carrijo, R. Miani, J. Souza, and V. Guizilini, “The Impact of DoS Attacks on the AR.Drone 2.0,” Proc. - 13th Lat. Am. Robot. Symp. 4th Brazilian Symp. Robot. LARS/SBR 2016, pp. 127–132, 2016, doi: 10.1109/LARS-SBR.2016.28.
references.description: This paper experimentally evaluates the impact of resource-based Denial of Service (DoS) attacks on the Parrot AR.Drone 2.0. The authors conduct an experimental study to observe how existing DoS tools affect UAV network availability and application performance, with a particular focus on video streaming. The experimental setup involves three main entities: (1) a pilot, who controls the AR.Drone using a laptop running ROS over a Wi-Fi connection; (2) the UAV (AR.Drone 2.0), which operates as a Wi-Fi access point without encryption or authentication; and (3) an attacker, who connects to the same wireless network using a laptop. The authors assume that the attacker is within wireless range and can freely join the UAV’s open Wi-Fi network. No WPA or WPA2 protection is enabled on the UAV, so the attacker does not need to bypass any authentication mechanisms. These assumptions reflect the default configuration of the AR.Drone 2.0 used in the experiments. The attack model consists of two phases. In the reconnaissance phase, the attacker uses Nmap to scan the UAV and identify open services, including FTP (port 21), Telnet (port 23), and the video streaming service (port 5555), all of which are accessible without credentials. In the attack phase, the attacker launches resource-based DoS attacks using three tools: LOIC to perform TCP SYN flooding, Netwox to conduct SYN flood attacks on specific ports, and Hping3 to generate high-rate packet floods. The attacks are executed while the UAV is operating normally, and their impact is measured in real time. The authors evaluate the effects of the DoS attacks using two main metrics. First, network latency between the pilot and the UAV is measured, showing that DoS attacks significantly increase latency on targeted ports, with Hping3 producing the highest latency increase. Second, video streaming performance is measured using ROS topic frequency, revealing a sharp drop in video frame rate during the attacks. The UAV does not consistently crash during the experiments, but its network-dependent functions, particularly real-time video streaming, experience severe degradation. The paper does not claim guaranteed loss of control and notes that firmware updates may mitigate some of the observed effects.

references.name: An Effective Countermeasure against UAV Swarm Attack
references.cite: D. He, G. Yang, H. Li, S. Chan, Y. Cheng, and N. Guizani, “An Effective Countermeasure against UAV Swarm Attack,” IEEE Netw., vol. 35, no. 1, pp. 380–385, 2021, doi: 10.1109/MNET.011.2000380.
references.description:
This paper studies GPS spoofing as a potential defensive approach against UAV swarm attacks. The core idea is to deceive the UAV swarm’s position perception system so that UAVs misjudge their locations and collide with each other, thereby disrupting the swarm. The contribution is simulation-based. The authors build a UAV swarm position perception simulation platform using ROS and Gazebo, implement GNSS deception, and demonstrate that two UAVs can be induced to collide under spoofed navigation signals.

The paper assumes a GNSS-dependent UAV swarm in which each UAV relies on GPS (or other GNSS) for position estimation, periodically updates its location from satellite signals, and uses this information for navigation and formation control. The UAVs are assumed to trust received GNSS signals and lack strong spoofing detection mechanisms. No software compromise, network intrusion, or remote control takeover is assumed.
 The defender is modeled as an entity capable of estimating the approximate positions of UAVs and broadcasting false but plausible GNSS position signals. The spoofing signals are generated using an adaptive algorithm that gradually shifts the UAVs’ perceived positions to avoid abrupt changes. The goal is not to take control of the UAVs, but to manipulate their perceived positions to induce unsafe relative motion.
 To demonstrate swarm disruption, the paper focuses on two UAVs as the minimal cooperative unit. The collision process consists of three steps: selecting a collision point, equalizing deceptive distances so both UAVs perceive safe trajectories, and applying collision-oriented position spoofing. Two scenarios are evaluated in simulation: parallel flight paths and intersecting flight paths. In both cases, GPS spoofing alone causes the UAVs to deviate from their intended paths and collide at a predefined point. The results show that GNSS deception can disrupt UAV swarm operation by exploiting the swarm’s reliance on cooperative positioning, but the evaluation is limited to simulation and does not include real-world flight tests.

references.name: Secure UAV Communication With Cooperative Jamming and Trajectory Control
references.cite: C. Zhong, J. Yao, and J. Xu, “Secure UAV Communication With Cooperative Jamming and Trajectory Control,” IEEE Commun. Lett., vol. 23, no. 2, pp. 286–289, 2019, doi: 10.1109/LCOMM.2018.2889062.
references.description:
This paper studies how to protect UAV-to-ground wireless communication from passive eavesdropping. The authors propose a cooperative jamming scheme in which one UAV sends confidential data to a legitimate ground node (GN), while a second UAV acts as a friendly jammer and transmits artificial noise to interfere with a ground eavesdropper. The work focuses on communication confidentiality rather than disrupting UAV operation or causing physical damage.
 The system consists of two UAVs, one ground node, and one passive ground eavesdropper. The UAVs fly at fixed, possibly different altitudes and have fully controllable horizontal mobility. The location of the ground node is assumed to be perfectly known, while the eavesdropper’s location is only partially known and modelled as a bounded uncertainty region. Air-to-ground channels are assumed to be dominated by line-of-sight propagation and follow a free-space path loss model.
 Security is achieved at the physical layer. The transmitting UAV sends confidential data to the ground node, while the jamming UAV emits artificial noise to reduce the signal quality at the eavesdropper. The jamming signal is carefully managed so that it limits information leakage without significantly degrading the legitimate communication. Because UAVs are mobile, their positions can be adjusted over time: the transmitting UAV can move closer to the ground node, and the jamming UAV can move closer to the eavesdropper.
 The authors formulate an optimisation problem that aims to maximise the average secrecy rate over a given mission duration. The variables to be optimised are the trajectories of both UAVs and their transmit powers. The problem is difficult to solve directly because the secrecy rate expression is non-convex, the eavesdropper’s location is uncertain, and the trajectory and power variables are tightly coupled.
 To address this, the authors first derive a conservative lower bound on the secrecy rate that accounts for the worst-case eavesdropper location. They then solve the problem using an iterative approach. At each step, they alternately optimise the transmit and jamming power for fixed UAV trajectories, and then optimise the UAV trajectories for fixed power levels. Each subproblem is approximated using successive convex approximation, which allows it to be solved efficiently using standard convex optimisation tools. This alternating process is guaranteed to converge to a locally optimal solution.
 Simulation results show that jointly optimising UAV trajectories and power allocation significantly improves the secrecy rate compared with baseline schemes, such as fixed fly-hover-fly trajectories or constant power transmission. The proposed approach is also shown to be robust to moderate uncertainty in the eavesdropper’s location. Overall, the paper demonstrates improvements in communication-level security, rather than physical disruption or control interference.

references.name: Security in networks of unmanned aerial vehicles for surveillance with an agent-based approach inspired by the principles of blockchain
references.cite: I. García-Magariño, R. Lacuesta, M. Rajarajan, and J. Lloret, “Security in networks of unmanned aerial vehicles for surveillance with an agent-based approach inspired by the principles of blockchain,” Ad Hoc Networks, vol. 86, pp. 72–82, 2019, doi: 10.1016/j.adhoc.2018.11.010.
references.description:
This paper studies security in UAV networks used for surveillance, focusing on the case where some official UAVs are physically hijacked and begin to behave maliciously. The target scenario is border or perimeter surveillance in areas with low human traffic and no fixed network infrastructure, where UAVs form a mobile ad-hoc UAV-to-UAV (V2V) network.
 The main security problem addressed is false information injection by compromised UAVs, such as reporting non-existent intruders in order to degrade trust in the surveillance system. The system consists of a fleet of officially registered UAVs that patrol a controlled area, detect people using onboard vision, and communicate only through short-range V2V links without relying on ground infrastructure or continuous connectivity.
 The approach is based on several key assumptions. All UAVs are pre-registered and know the public keys of other official UAVs. UAVs may be physically hijacked, but attackers cannot steal private keys from other UAVs. A real intruder is normally observed by more than one UAV, although not always at the same time. Communication between UAVs is intermittent rather than continuous.
 To address this problem, the paper proposes a distributed defence mechanism inspired by blockchain principles and combined with a trust policy. When a UAV observes a person, it creates a signed message using asymmetric cryptography, which includes its UAV ID and the observation. This prevents identity spoofing, since only the UAV holding the private key can generate valid signatures. Observations are then shared in a blockchain-like manner, where information is propagated peer-to-peer and UAVs maintain local copies of the longest valid chain, making later modification difficult.

In addition, a corroboration-based trust policy is used. Events reported by multiple UAVs are considered trustworthy, while events repeatedly reported by only a single UAV are treated as suspicious and reduce that UAV’s trust score over time. Even though a hijacked UAV can still send correctly signed messages, it can be identified as untrustworthy if its alerts are never corroborated by others.
 The approach is evaluated using a custom agent-based simulator called ABS-SecurityUAV, implemented in NetLogo. The evaluation does not involve real UAVs. Simulations use 100 UAVs moving in a two-dimensional space with non-deterministic movement to avoid predictability. Two main scenarios are tested: one where a real person crosses the area with no compromised UAVs, and one where a single compromised UAV sends false alerts without any real intruder.
 Measured outcomes include the percentage of UAVs that receive alerts, the percentage that trust the alerts, and the number of direct observers per event. Results show that real intrusions are gradually trusted by most UAVs, while false alerts from a compromised UAV may spread but are never trusted due to lack of corroboration. As a result, compromised UAVs can be detected over time without revoking cryptographic keys, purely through trust degradation.

references.name: Securing of Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) against security threats using human immune system
references.cite: R. Fotohi, “Securing of Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) against security threats using human immune system,” Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 193, no. August 2019, p. 106675, 2020, doi: 10.1016/j.ress.2019.106675.
references.description:
This paper addresses security threats in Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS), focusing on UAV ad-hoc networks where UAVs cooperate to forward data and maintain communication without fixed infrastructure. The paper assumes that UAVs form a MANET-like network, that some UAVs may become malicious due to compromise or misbehaviour, and that these malicious UAVs aim to disrupt routing or communication rather than fully take control of the system.
The paper considers several routing- and communication-level attacks. In a wormhole attack, two colluding malicious UAVs tunnel packets between distant locations, creating the illusion of a short route and attracting traffic through them. In a black hole attack, a malicious UAV advertises a fake optimal route and then drops all forwarded packets. In a grey hole attack, a malicious UAV selectively drops packets, behaving normally at times and maliciously at others, making detection harder. In false information or GPS deception attacks, a UAV injects incorrect location or routing-related information to mislead network decisions and degrade communication reliability.
To address these threats, the paper proposes an intrusion detection system inspired by the Human Immune System, called SUAS-HIS. The system treats abnormal network behaviour as antigens and detection patterns as antibodies. It focuses on behavioural detection rather than signature-based detection, monitoring routing and communication behaviour to distinguish normal and malicious activity. The design applies immune-system concepts such as negative selection, affinity, and clonal selection to identify abnormal behaviour patterns.
The approach is evaluated through simulation using NS-3, not real UAV hardware. Multiple attack scenarios are simulated, including wormhole, black hole, grey hole, and false information attacks. Performance is measured using detection rate, packet delivery ratio, false positive rate, and false negative rate.
Simulation results show that SUAS-HIS achieves higher detection rates than the compared methods across multiple attack types, identifies and isolates malicious UAVs before severe communication degradation occurs, and improves packet delivery ratio once malicious nodes are detected. The results are limited to the simulated scenarios and parameters used. The proposed method is compared against a generic cybersecurity system, a behaviour-rule-based IDS (BRUIDS), and SFA-based approaches.

references.name: A machine learning based attack in UAV communication networks
references.cite: X. C. Chen and Y. J. Chen, “A machine learning based attack in UAV communication networks,” IEEE Veh. Technol. Conf., vol. 2019-Septe, pp. 1–2, 2019, doi: 10.1109/VTCFall.2019.8891199.
references.description:
This paper studies a privacy attack on UAV communication, focusing on encrypted UAV location broadcasts sent from the UAV to a ground base station (GBS). The system model assumes that UAVs periodically transmit GPS-based location data over a wireless channel while operating in a fixed geographic area. The attacker is passive and does not inject traffic or compromise UAV hardware, but can eavesdrop on wireless transmissions and visually observe the UAV when it is within line of sight.
 The core attack model is a known-plaintext attack (KPA) assisted by machine learning. The attacker collects ciphertext through wireless monitoring and obtains partial plaintext by observing the UAV’s real location during limited observation periods. These plaintext–ciphertext pairs are used to train a neural network to learn the relationship between encrypted messages and underlying location data. The paper assumes a shared encryption key across UAVs and a simple XOR-based encryption scheme applied to binary-encoded location information.
 The feasibility of the attack is evaluated through simulations. Results show that longer attacker observation time and a higher number of simultaneously operating UAVs reduce the neural network’s bit error rate, allowing more accurate inference of UAV location data. The paper does not demonstrate UAV takeover, command manipulation, or real-world deployment, and focuses strictly on location privacy leakage under the stated assumptions.

references.name: On simulation-based adaptive UAS behavior during jamming
references.cite: R. Johansson, P. Hammar, and P. Thoren, “On simulation-based adaptive UAS behavior during jamming,” 2017 Work. Res. Educ. Dev. Unmanned Aer. Syst. RED-UAS 2017, pp. 78–83, 2017, doi: 10.1109/RED-UAS.2017.8101647.
references.description:
This paper studies autonomous behaviour of a UAS when its communication link is jammed, focusing on how the aircraft should adapt its flight path after losing remote control. The scenario assumes a remotely piloted aerial system (RPAS) performing a surveillance mission, where an adversary deliberately jams the communication uplink and downlink to disrupt control and sensor data transmission. Once the link is jammed, the aircraft must operate autonomously. The radar sensor is assumed to remain functional, while communication is unavailable. 
 The authors highlight a weakness of standard fail-safe behaviour, where a jammed aircraft immediately returns to a pre-defined safe location (e.g., home base). In such cases, an adversary can effectively force mission abortion simply by jamming communications. To address this, the paper considers an alternative objective: the UAS should continue surveilling the jammed area for a limited time to detect threats, but still exit the jammed region early enough to report detected information once communication is restored. 
 The problem is formulated as a flight path planning and policy selection problem under uncertainty. Rather than continuous control or reinforcement learning, the authors propose a stochastic approximation approach that selects a complete flight path in a single decision. Candidate paths are represented using quadratic Bézier curves, defined by the aircraft’s current position, a selected direction, and an endpoint constrained to the estimated boundary between jammed and non-jammed areas. The action space consists of a discrete set of direction choices and allowed flight times within the jammed region. 
 The policy is learned through extensive simulation, not real-world deployment. The authors use the FLAMES simulator to model a military coastal surveillance scenario in which a jammer disrupts communications while cruise missiles may be launched toward defended targets. For each predefined attack scenario and each possible flight-path option, multiple simulation runs are executed. The performance metric is based on how many cruise missiles are detected before the UAS exits the jammed area and regains communication. 
 The results show that different path and timing choices lead to significantly different surveillance outcomes. In some scenarios, adaptive path planning allows the UAS to detect more threats than the default behaviour of immediately returning to base. However, the paper does not prescribe a single optimal policy. Instead, it presents a methodology that allows operators to explore trade-offs between detection performance and reporting delay using simulation-based evaluation.

references.name: Packet Insertion Attack Detection in Optical UAV Networks
references.cite: N. Ramdhan, M. Sliti, and N. Boudriga, “Packet Insertion Attack Detection in Optical UAV Networks,” Int. Conf. Transparent Opt. Networks, vol. 2018-July, pp. 1–5, 2018, doi: 10.1109/ICTON.2018.8473952.
references.description:
This paper studies security issues in optical UAV networks where UAVs communicate with each other using Free Space Optical (FSO) links. The system model assumes a three-layer UAV architecture: UAVs collect data from ground sensors, forward it through inter-UAV FSO links organised in a tree structure, and finally deliver the data to base stations. The focus is on protecting inter-UAV communication, not UAV control or navigation. 
 The authors consider a specific external packet insertion attack on inter-UAV FSO links. In this attack, an adversary positioned on the optical link injects false or erroneous data packets so that the receiving UAV accepts corrupted information as legitimate. The attacker does not take over UAV control and does not break cryptographic keys; instead, the attack targets the data transmission channel itself. 
 To detect packet insertion attacks, the paper proposes an optical codeword–based encoding scheme. Each data bit is encoded using predefined optical codewords and their cyclically shifted replicas. Two base codewords are used to represent binary values, and additional security is introduced by varying the starting index of the codeword shifts for each communication session. At the receiver, packets are decoded using optical decoders configured with the expected codeword patterns. If a packet cannot be correctly decoded, it is treated as evidence of a packet insertion attack. 
 Beyond detection, the paper proposes a tolerance mechanism rather than a full recovery or fail-safe system. When a packet insertion attack is detected, the UAV may respond by changing the spatial or temporal characteristics of the FSO link or by physically repositioning itself to alter the optical communication path. 
 The authors evaluate the proposed approach using simulation, analysing trade-offs between security and performance. Results show that longer codewords and more codeword shifts improve attack resistance but reduce data rate and optical signal quality. The paper concludes that a balance must be chosen between security strength, latency, and throughput.

references.name: A Cognitive Radio System for Improving the Reliability and Security of UAS/UAV Networks
references.cite: H. Reyes, N. Gellerman, and N. Kaabouch, “A Cognitive Radio System for Improving the Reliability and Security of UAS/UAV Networks” 2015 IEEE Aerosp. Conf., pp. 1–9, doi: 10.1109/AERO.2015.7119159.
references.description:
This paper proposes a defence-oriented communication system that improves the reliability and availability of wireless links in Unmanned Aerial System (UAS/UAV) networks. The focus is on the communication layer, where UAVs frequently experience lost links due to mobility, long distances, obstacles, interference, and jamming. Rather than assuming stable network conditions, the paper treats link disruption as a normal and expected situation in UAV operations.
The paper assumes a UAS architecture in which UAVs communicate wirelessly with ground stations and with other vehicles. Different UAV platforms may operate on different frequency bands, such as UHF, C-band, Ku-band, or L-band, depending on mission range and whether communication is line-of-sight or beyond line-of-sight. The authors note that UAS networks do not follow a single communication standard and often lack guaranteed end-to-end connectivity, which makes them more vulnerable to communication failures.
The main contribution is a cognitive radio system implemented using software-defined radio. Software-defined radio allows the UAV to change its radio behaviour using software rather than fixed hardware. On top of this, the cognitive radio continuously observes the radio environment, decides how severe the communication problem is, and adapts its transmission settings to keep the link alive. To understand the environment, the system measures which frequencies are occupied, how strong and reliable the signal is, and how UAV motion affects the signal through Doppler shift.
Based on these observations, the UAV can dynamically adjust how it transmits data. For example, it can switch to a different frequency if the current one is congested or jammed, reduce the data rate to make communication more robust under noise, increase error correction when packets are being lost, adjust transmission power when the signal becomes weak, or change bandwidth when more or less capacity is needed.
To increase reliability, the paper describes two types of defence mechanisms: prevention and recovery. Prevention mechanisms aim to avoid link failure before it happens by detecting interference early and preparing alternative channels, including maintaining backup frequencies. Recovery mechanisms are used after a failure has occurred and focus on restoring communication by switching channels, aggregating bandwidth, or adapting modulation and coding to degraded conditions.
The paper also implements a fuzzy logic–based detection system to identify lost links and possible jamming. This system uses simple communication measurements, such as packet loss, signal strength, channel availability, and delivery ratio, to determine whether the link is healthy, degraded, or under jamming. Simulation and field experiments show that the system can accurately detect link loss and distinguish between different causes, including interference, propagation loss, and several types of jamming.

references.name: Ad-hoc framework for efficient network security for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV)
references.cite: M. S. Haque and M. U. Chowdhury, Ad-hoc framework for efficient network security for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV), vol. 1113 CCIS. Springer International Publishing, 2019. doi: 10.1007/978-3-030-34353-8_2.
references.description:
This paper addresses network security challenges in WiFi-based UAV ad-hoc networks, with a focus on resource-constrained commercial UAV platforms. The authors observe that many civilian UAVs rely on IEEE 802.11 wireless links for command, control, and data transmission, often with weak or disabled security mechanisms due to performance and energy constraints. As a result, UAV networks are vulnerable to eavesdropping, jamming, denial-of-service, buffer overflow, and hijacking attacks conducted over exposed wireless links. 
The paper assumes a UAV ad-hoc network architecture composed of UAVs and a ground control station (GCS), where communication occurs over open wireless channels without fixed infrastructure. UAVs are treated as resource-limited nodes, with constraints on battery capacity, computation, storage, and bandwidth. The authors focus primarily on micro UAV platforms commonly used in commercial settings, such as the Parrot AR.Drone and Bebop series, which operate using unencrypted or weakly protected WiFi links and run embedded Linux-based systems. 
 The paper proposes a multi-layer, hierarchical security framework for UAV ad-hoc networks that uses Identity-Based Encryption (IBE) to secure communication while reducing key management overhead. Instead of relying on traditional public-key infrastructure and certificate authorities, the framework derives public keys directly from node identities (e.g., device identifiers). This design aims to reduce communication overhead, simplify key distribution, and make cryptographic protection more feasible for UAVs with limited resources. The proposed network architecture organises UAVs into a hierarchical clustering structure consisting of a base station, cluster heads, and ordinary cluster members. Cluster heads are assumed to have relatively higher computational and energy capabilities compared to ordinary UAV nodes. Security-related operations, including key management, authentication, and aggregation of encrypted data, are offloaded to cluster heads to reduce the burden on resource-constrained UAVs. Ordinary cluster members communicate only with their assigned cluster head, which forwards and processes data before sending it to the base station. 
 To evaluate feasibility, the paper presents a simulation-based experimental study using OMNeT++ and the INET framework. The authors model a UAV network based on a Parrot Bebop platform and focus on measuring the energy and power consumption associated with IBE operations, particularly during key management and message encryption. The evaluation is intended to assess whether IBE can be practically deployed in UAV networks without significantly reducing flight time. The results focus on energy consumption and feasibility rather than attack resistance or security effectiveness against specific adversaries.

references.name: ETD: An Efficient Time Delay Attack Detection Framework for UAV Networks
references.cite: W. Zhai, L. Liu, Y. Ding, S. Sun, and Y. Gu, “ETD: An Efficient Time Delay Attack Detection Framework for UAV Networks,” IEEE Trans. Inf. Forensics Secur., vol. 18, pp. 2913–2928, 2023, doi: 10.1109/TIFS.2023.3272862.
references.description:
This paper studies a specific internal attack in UAV networks called a time delay attack. In this attack, a compromised UAV does not drop or modify packets. Instead, it intentionally delays forwarding packets, which can cause serious damage in time-critical UAV missions such as search-and-rescue or military reconnaissance. Because packets are still delivered correctly but late, this attack is hard to detect and cannot be handled by traditional encryption-based security. 
 The authors focus on multi-hop UAV networks that use a store-carry-and-forward communication model. In these networks, UAVs move along pre-planned trajectories, meet other UAVs opportunistically, and forward data hop by hop to a ground station. This mobility and intermittent connectivity make normal delays common, which allows malicious delay behavior to hide among legitimate network behavior. 
 The paper proposes ETD (Efficient Time Delay Attack Detection), a lightweight detection framework deployed at the ground station. ETD does not rely on packet content inspection or cryptographic checks. Instead, it detects attacks by analysing forwarding behaviour of UAVs over time. The key idea is to measure the real forwarding delay of each UAV, rather than the end-to-end delivery delay of a packet. To do this, the framework uses pre-planned trajectory information to remove the normal “store and carry” time caused by UAV movement. This allows ETD to estimate how long a UAV actually waits before forwarding a packet, which reveals malicious delay behavior. 
 To support detection, each UAV attaches lightweight delay-related logs to packets as they are forwarded. These logs are collected at the ground station and used to extract features from four dimensions: Delay features (real forwarding delay), node features (buffer occupancy, speed, direction, transmission power), message features (packet size, source, destination, TTL), and connection features (distance, link quality). 
 Because labeled attack data is difficult to obtain, ETD uses one-class classification, trained only on normal (benign) forwarding behaviour. Each forwarding action is evaluated, and a trust value is calculated for every UAV based on how often it behaves normally or abnormally. Finally, K-Means clustering is applied to separate malicious UAVs from benign ones based on their trust values. The framework is evaluated using extensive simulations in the ONE simulator across multiple routing protocols (Epidemic, Spray-and-Wait, Probabilistic, and MaxProp). Results show that ETD achieves over 80–90% detection accuracy with less than 2.5% communication overhead, demonstrating that the approach is both effective and lightweight.

references.name: Detecting signal spoofing and jamming attacks in UAV networks using a lightweight IDS
references.cite: M. P. Arthur, “Detecting signal spoofing and jamming attacks in UAV networks using a lightweight IDS,” CITS 2019 - Proceeding 2019 Int. Conf. Comput. Inf. Telecommun. Syst., pp. 1–5, 2019, doi: 10.1109/CITS.2019.8862148.
references.description:
This paper studies signal spoofing and jamming attacks in UAV networks, with a focus on GPS spoofing and communication jamming. It argues that existing UAV autopilot systems are vulnerable because they rely heavily on GPS-based navigation and basic collision avoidance, which cannot reliably handle malicious signal interference. The paper assumes that UAVs operate in a delay-tolerant network (DTN) with intermittent connectivity, use epidemic routing, and may be targeted by external attackers operating from ground stations or nearby vehicles. Attacks are assumed to be random in time, location, duration, and target. The UAV is assumed to switch into autopilot mode when contact with the control station is lost, and this autopilot mode fully relies on GPS information, making it susceptible to spoofing.

The paper describes a conceptual two-stage attack model in which a jamming attack first disrupts communication with the control station, forcing the UAV into autopilot mode, followed by a GPS spoofing attack that feeds false location data and causes the UAV to land in an attacker-chosen or hostile zone. These attacks are described and simulated but not implemented on real UAV hardware.

The main contribution of the paper is a defence-oriented, lightweight, distributed intrusion detection system (IDS) deployed across the UAV on-board system, the control station, ground stations, and neighboring UAVs. The IDS consists of three phases. The self-analysis phase continuously logs flight and network data such as GPS locations, flight mode changes, velocity, connectivity status, and routing information, producing around 200 features during simulation. The self-detection phase uses Self-Taught Learning (STL) to extract features from unlabeled data and a multiclass SVM to classify behavior as normal, GPS spoofing, jamming, or combined attacks. The self-routing phase proposes a Q-learning-based recovery mechanism to guide the UAV back to home or a safe zone, but this phase is described as future work and is not fully implemented.

The system is evaluated using simulation only, based on the ONE DTN simulator with 20 UAVs and simulated spoofing and jamming attacks. Performance is measured using accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. Results show that the STL-assisted multiclass SVM outperforms a standalone SVM in detecting the simulated attacks. No real-world flight experiments or hardware validation are provided.

references.name: Security authentication system using encrypted channel on UAV network
references.cite: K. Yoon, D. Park, Y. Yim, K. Kim, S. K. Yang, and M. Robinson, “Security authentication system using encrypted channel on UAV network,” Proc. - 2017 1st IEEE Int. Conf. Robot. Comput. IRC 2017, pp. 393–398, 2017, doi: 10.1109/IRC.2017.56.
references.description:
This paper addresses UAV hijacking and unauthorised control resulting from insecure wireless communication channels in commercial UAVs. It focuses on scenarios in which attackers exploit weak or unprotected Wi-Fi links to disrupt communication, perform denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, or take control of the UAV. The work is explicitly defence-oriented and aims to maintain or regain control of the UAV after a communication hijack, rather than analysing or proposing new attack techniques.

The paper assumes that commercial UAVs rely on wireless communication (e.g., Wi-Fi) between the UAV and a ground station (GS), and that external and anonymous attackers can perform network-level attacks such as DoS, ARP spoofing, man-in-the-middle, or channel hijacking. It also assumes that UAVs may be physically accessed after landing and that existing UAV systems lack strong authentication and encrypted communication channels.
 To address these issues, the paper proposes a three-party system model consisting of a ground station (GS), a middleware device (Raspberry Pi) directly connected to the UAV, and the UAV itself. Two communication channels are used: a primary channel for standard UAV communication and a secondary encrypted channel for secure control and authentication. The middleware manages both channels, monitors the primary channel for abnormal behaviour, and can disable or disrupt the compromised channel to prevent data leakage or attacker control.
 The core technical contribution is an encrypted authentication protocol between the UAV (via the Raspberry Pi) and the GS. Before take-off, the GS and UAV synchronise time-based random values using an NTP server. These values are stored in a shared key table and used with AES encryption. During flight, the UAV and GS periodically perform a challenge–response authentication using encrypted index values. If authentication fails, the communication channel is terminated. The protocol is designed to mitigate reflection attacks by ensuring that authentication values are not directly exposed or reused in plaintext.
 When a network intrusion or hijacking attempt is detected, the GS can instruct the middleware to disable the primary communication channel, while maintaining control through the encrypted secondary channel when possible. In extreme cases, the GS can issue a destruction signal that triggers a MOSFET-based hardware circuit to disable UAV components or short the battery, aiming to protect sensitive data if the UAV is physically compromised.
 The system is implemented using a Raspberry Pi 3 as middleware, AES-based encryption, WPA2 Wi-Fi communication, and commercial UAV platforms. Evaluation focuses on communication delay (approximately 10 seconds of added latency), CPU overhead on the Raspberry Pi (over 80% usage), and the ability to regain control via the encrypted channel after a DoS attack on the primary channel.

references.name: An Uncrewed Aerial Vehicle Attack Scenario and Trustworthy Repair Architecture
references.cite: K. Highnam, K. Angstadt, K. Leach, W. Weimer, A. Paulos, and P. Hurley, “An Uncrewed Aerial Vehicle Attack Scenario and Trustworthy Repair Architecture,” Proc. - 46th Annu. IEEE/IFIP Int. Conf. Dependable Syst. Networks, DSN-W 2016, pp. 222–225, 2016, doi: 10.1109/DSN-W.2016.63.
references.description:
This paper studies a realistic attack scenario against commodity unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and proposes a defence architecture focused on resilience and trust recovery, rather than prevention alone. The authors consider UAVs that use open-source autopilot software and communicate with ground stations using the MAVLink protocol, which is unencrypted and unauthenticated. The UAV platform assumed in the paper is a commodity quadcopter running open-source autopilot software on a Unix-like operating system with a real-time kernel. The UAV communicates with a ground control station using MAVLink over radio telemetry. MAVLink messages include flight commands and telemetry data such as position, heading, speed, and sensor readings. Communication relies only on a system ID and does not use cryptographic protection. This architecture is representative of widely used platforms such as 3DR IRIS+, Erle-Copter, and Raspberry Pi–based UAVs. 
 The paper assumes an attacker equipped with a commodity computer, open-source ground station software, and a directional antenna. The attacker does not need physical access to the UAV and does not compromise the onboard software directly. Instead, the attacker exploits the lack of authentication in MAVLink by spoofing MAVLink packets after capturing the UAV’s system ID. The attacker’s goal is subtle mission degradation, not a crash or overt takeover. In the described scenario, the UAV is performing a waypoint-based surveillance mission. When the UAV enters the attacker’s radio “cone of influence,” the attacker injects malicious MAVLink messages (such as position or heading commands) that slightly alter the flight path. This causes the UAV to miss or incorrectly execute one or more waypoints, resulting in mission failure while avoiding obvious detection. 
 Rather than relying on cryptographic protection, the authors propose runtime attack detection based on telemetry consistency. The ground station continuously monitors UAV telemetry and compares it against expected mission profiles derived from simulation and prior flights. Multiple telemetry sources are cross-checked to detect inconsistencies. For example, magnetometer readings are compared against expected heading clusters for a known flight path. Even if GPS data is spoofed, inconsistencies between GPS and magnetometer data may reveal abnormal behaviour. Once an attack is detected, the system does not attempt to remove the attacker. Instead, it automatically synthesises a repaired flight plan that avoids the attacker’s cone of influence while still achieving the mission goals. This is done using automated program repair techniques, such as GenProg. The flight plan can be represented either as a sequence of MAVLink packets or as a higher-level program that issues MAVLink commands. Candidate repaired flight plans are evaluated in simulation using an objective function that measures mission success (e.g., number of waypoints completed) and penalises risky behaviour (e.g., proximity to the attack region). The best candidate is then deployed mid-flight. After deployment, telemetry is monitored again to evaluate whether trust in the UAV’s behaviour can be re-established.
